Hey,
  I like the challenge. I've just wrote a c# solution, all test are ok. I am hesitating whether it is easy or medium, it may stay medium because of the non separated grid input.

  I'd suggest one rewording, either "vertical speed is -1m/s" or "vertical speed is 1m/s downwards" to be specific.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

One thing about the description:
 - y step of the grid is 1 meter
 - x step of the grid is 10 seconds
Shouldn't they be the same unit?
How are those units reflected in the paraglider movement? In the example, it moves only one position on each axes per step.
Also, what makes the paraglider go up and down in the example provided since it does not 'land' on any number?

I enjoyed the contribution but have some comments on the description and example:

While the description uses the term "increased" and "decreased" altitude the output requires the grid position, starting at the highest altitude and increases when going down. After reading the description i would have expected that an higher altitude at the simulations end would result in a higher second number in the result.

For example i would have expected the following position to be "2 2" not "2 0"

..V..
.....
.....

This is especially problematic since it is impossible to see in the given example.


Aside from that it is mildly irritating that width and height are constant but the example uses another height and width. I would change the example or (and this is what i would prefer) make height and width input parameters .

Beside from that i would would like to see the challenge being approved/upvoted.

Hi, The_Ghost,

Both of your remarks are relevant, thanks for sharing it !

I guess you're right about the final position, I use to have a reverse y axis on grid puzzle but in that case it would be more logical to have a normal representation,
Now it's fixed !

About the map sizes, I will change it, I wanted to have an example in the description that would not take too much space, but as you wrote, it's a bit confusing, so I'll add different sizes !

It could be same unit but I wanted values that match at least a little bit the real paraglider performances. It doesn't change at all for the puzzle, but it make the subject more... coherent.

"Here we consider our paraglider vertical speed is 1m/s and horizontal speed is 10m/s"
It means each turn, the glider go right by one step and down by one step (in case there is no thermal activity value on the cell)
[ ! ] I should maybe say in the description that it goes from left to right, I add it !

Actually in the example I don't show the step between because it's counted as one turn, but to explain in one turn, the paraglider goes down right, and if it encounter a thermal activity it modify vertical position : y += grid[posy][posx]

Yes basically it was set as "easy", but many feedbacks pushed me to turn it to medium !
Good advice for vertical speed, i'm updating it.
Thanks for feedback :)

not all grids work that way.  cartesian planes have 0,0 in the center, or bottom left.

I think in this use case, having the height above the ground for the y coordinate makes sense.
Yes too bad it wasn't edited prior to approval, the space separator is the way to go if values given on a line don't have a constant size.
Thanks NeoJex, you wrote what I wanted to say !
The CG standard is top left
agreed, but this seems to me to be more like a simulation, than a CG exercise.

To be clear, I've coded a solution and I've upvoted and I'm ready to approve.  It is just a standard CG practice to have 0,0 be top left.  It really helps reduced confusion and make reading in the data much easier, as the first line is [0], and the second line is [1], etc.  I'll definitely approve this is the coordinates are changed.
-Warm regards

Hello, it depends of the abstraction layer of the puzzle, this is a logical choice, I've not reversed the grid for no reason. On a different case where the grid would be an abstract table it would be more accurate to have standard coordinates system, but this problem is based on a IRL reference so I choose to make it like this.
the Y value represent the altitude, If I reverse it the altitude on top will be 0, and on the bottom the max, it would be confusing. Sorry but I'm not changing it !
I believe it's ok if the puzzle doesn't use the CG "standards" for a grid. Perhaps an highlighted warning could avoid confusion.

I guess this is the best compromise, I'll add a warning on subject description üëç
[Edited] Done !
Congratulations on getting it approved.  Thanks Thibaud for the clarification.
Map-size update has been done üëç
